author: Grimms
text: Once upon a time there was a man who did nothing but gamble, and for that reason people never called him anything but Gambling Hansel, and as he never ceased to gamble, he played away his house and all that he had.

author: Grimms
text: Now the very day before his creditors were to take his house from him, came the Lord and St. Peter, and asked him to give them shelter for the night.

author: Grimms
text: Then Gambling Hansel said, "For my part, you may stay the night, but I cannot give you a bed or anything to eat."

author: Grimms
text: So the Lord said he was just to take them in, and they themselves would buy something to eat, to which Gambling Hansel made no objection.

author: Grimms
text: Thereupon St. Peter gave him three groschen, and said he was to go to the baker"s and fetch some bread.

author: Grimms
text: So Gambling Hansel went, but when he reached the house where the other gambling vagabonds were gathered together, they, although they had won all that he had, greeted him clamorously, and said, "Hansel, do come in."

author: Grimms
text: "Oh," said he, "do you want to win the three groschen too?"

author: Grimms
text: On this they would not let him go.

author: Grimms
text: So he went in, and played away the three groschen also.

author: Grimms
text: Meanwhile St. Peter and the Lord were waiting, and as he was so long in coming, they set out to meet him.

author: Grimms
text: When Gambling Hansel came, however, he pretended that the money had fallen into the gutter, and kept raking about in it all the while to find it, but our Lord already knew that he had lost it in play.

author: Grimms
text: St. Peter again gave him three groschen, and now he did not allow himself to be led away once more, but fetched them the loaf.

author: Grimms
text: Our Lord then inquired if he had no wine, and he said, "Alack, sir, the casks are all empty!"

author: Grimms
text: But the Lord said he was to go down into the cellar, for the best wine was still there.

author: Grimms
text: For a long time he would not believe this, but at length he said, "Well, I will go down, but I know that there is none there."

author: Grimms
text: When he turned the tap, however, lo and behold, the best of wine ran out!

author: Grimms
text: So he took it to them, and the two passed the night there.

author: Grimms
text: Early next day our Lord told Gambling Hansel that he might beg three favours.

author: Grimms
text: The Lord expected that he would ask to go to Heaven; but Gambling Hansel asked for a pack of cards with which he could win everything, for dice with which he would win everything, and for a tree whereon every kind of fruit would grow, and from which no one who had climbed up, could descend until he bade him do so.

author: Grimms
text: The Lord gave him all that he had asked, and departed with St. Peter.

author: Grimms
text: And now Gambling Hansel at once set about gambling in real earnest, and before long he had gained half the world.

author: Grimms
text: Upon this St. Peter said to the Lord, "Lord, this thing must not go on, he will win, and thou lose, the whole world.

author: Grimms
text: We must send Death to him."

author: Grimms
text: When Death appeared, Gambling Hansel had just seated himself at the gaming-table, and Death said, "Hansel, come out a while."

author: Grimms
text: But Gambling Hansel said, "Just wait a little until the game is done, and in the meantime get up into that tree out there, and gather a little fruit that we may have something to munch on our way."

author: Grimms
text: Thereupon Death climbed up, but when he wanted to come down again, he could not, and Gambling Hansel left him up there for seven years, during which time no one died.

author: Grimms
text: So St. Peter said to the Lord, "Lord, this thing must not go on.

author: Grimms
text: People no longer die; we must go ourselves."

author: Grimms
text: And they went themselves, and the Lord commanded Hansel to let Death come down.

author: Grimms
text: So Hansel went at once to Death and said to him, "Come down," and Death took him directly and put an end to him.

author: Grimms
text: They went away together and came to the next world, and then Gambling Hansel made straight for the door of Heaven, and knocked at it.

author: Grimms
text: "Who is there?"

author: Grimms
text: "Gambling Hansel."

author: Grimms
text: "Ah, we will have nothing to do with him!

author: Grimms
text: Begone!"

author: Grimms
text: So he went to the door of Purgatory, and knocked once more.

author: Grimms
text: "Who is there?"

author: Grimms
text: "Gambling Hansel."

author: Grimms
text: "Ah, there is quite enough weeping and wailing here without him.

author: Grimms
text: We do not want to gamble, just go away again."

author: Grimms
text: Then he went to the door of Hell, and there they let him in.

author: Grimms
text: There was, however, no one at home but old Lucifer and the crooked devils who had just been doing their evil work in the world.

author: Grimms
text: And no sooner was Hansel there than he sat down to gamble again.

author: Grimms
text: Lucifer, however, had nothing to lose, but his mis-shapen devils, and Gambling Hansel won them from him, as with his cards he could not fail to do.

author: Grimms
text: And now he was off again with his crooked devils, and they went to Hohenfuert and pulled up a hop-pole, and with it went to Heaven and began to thrust the pole against it, and Heaven began to crack.

author: Grimms
text: So again St. Peter said, "Lord, this thing cannot go on, we must let him in, or he will throw us down from Heaven."

author: Grimms
text: And they let him in.

author: Grimms
text: But Gambling Hansel instantly began to play again, and there was such a noise and confusion that there was no hearing what they themselves were saying.

author: Grimms
text: Therefore St. Peter once more said, "Lord, this cannot go on, we must throw him down, or he will make all Heaven rebellious."

author: Grimms
text: So they went to him at once, and threw him down, and his soul broke into fragments, and went into the gambling vagabonds who are living this very day.
